!! How One was Helped by a Loon
!! Swanton page 93 = 353
!! Optimized for Haida spellchecker, with big underlines g̲k̲x̲ and curly apostʼrophes
!! Version -- May 15, 2016


\cit 003:001
\swa Qaik! lnagaˊ-i gᵘ nᴀñ īˊłiña x̣ūˊᴀdjî da xᴀˊlaᵋāˊ-iyagan lʼ hit!ᴀˊn-īnaˊs ʟ̣ū ᴀ.
\mod K̲áaykʼ ʼlan-gáay gu nang íihlangaa xúuj da x̲aláa g̲áayaagaan, ʼll hatʼán ináas dluu aa.
\eng At Qaik! lived a man who had been a very good grisly-bear hunter when he was young.
\src 0353:03

\cit 003:002
\swa Lʼ ʟ!dagīˊ-īgañan. 
\mod ʼLl tlʼadáa gíigaangaan.
\eng He always killed them.
\src 0353:04

\cit 003:003
\swa ʟēł tc!îˊnłᴀwañ; stᴀˊnsîñ lʼ tc!îˊnłᴀwañ. 
\mod Tléehl tsʼánhlaawaan; stánsang ʼll tsʼánhlaawaan.
\eng Sometimes he shot five; sometimes he shot four.
\src 0353:05

\cit 003:004
\swa Hîn lʼ wᴀgīˊ-īgañan. 
\mod Hín ʼll ʼwáa gíigaangaan.
\eng He kept on doing it.
\src 0353:06

\cit 003:005
\swa Wᴀˊgiên ᵋa-i lʼ q!aiyᵋēˊlan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan g̲íi ʼll k̲ʼáyʼeelaan.
\eng And he grew old in (the profession).
\src 0353:07

\cit 003:006
\swa Waˊʟ̣u Qaik! lnagaˊ-i gᵘ gᴀm lagᵃ ʟ! gīˊdᵋañūgañan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu k̲áykʼ ʼLan-gáay gw gám ʼláa gä tlʼ gíidaʼangʼugaangaan.
\eng Then they did not give food to him at the town of Qaik!.
\src 0353:08

\cit 003:007
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ʟᴀgᴀˊnłañē lʼ tc!îˊte-îdan x̣ūˊᴀdjî dᴀ giagᵘ lʼ îˊsīgᴀñ-gañan ᵋa ᴀ. 
\mod ʼWáadluu tlagánhlangee ʼll tsʼatéedaan, xúuwajii dä gyáagw ʼll isigánggaangaan g̲aa aa.
\eng And he went to live in an uninhabited place where he used to hunt grisly bear.
\src 0353:09

\cit 003:008
\swa Djaˊᵋᴀñ ᴀł lʼ stᴀˊñyak!agan.
\mod Jáaʼang ahl ʼll sdáng yahkʼáagaan.
\eng He and his wife were the only two there.
\src 0353:10

\cit 003:009
\swa Wᴀgiêˊn gᵘ lʼ isāˊᵋawan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan gu ʼll isáaʼaawaan.
\eng And there they continued to live.
\src 0353:11

\cit 003:010
\swa Na-i wᴀgᵘ lᵋāˊña k!ūˊdagīgañan. 
\mod Náay ʼwáa gw ʼláangaa kʼúudaa gíigaangaan.
\eng His house always stood there.
\src 0353:12

\cit 003:011
\swa Gᴀm gîn tāˊłiñē qäñgāˊñan. 
\mod Gám gin táa hlangée k̲éenggaaʼaangaan.
\eng Nothing that they might eat was to be seen.
\src 0353:13

\cit 003:012
\swa Tāˊwē hīˊlawan. 
\mod Táawaay híilaawaan.
\eng The food was consumed.
\src 0353:14

\cit 003:013
\swa Tcaˊʼa-wᵋełs ʟ̣ū k!iū sᵋōˊnan lʼ łᵃāˊ-igañan.
\mod Chaawéehls dluu, kʼyúu sg̲únaan ʼll hlg̲áygaangaan.
\eng When the tide was low, she dug clams.
\src 0353:15

\cit 003:014
\swa Wᴀˊgiên qēgᵘ x̣ᴀˊdjuwa-i ᵋa-i k!īˊwē lʼ x̣ᴀsūˊgañan k!aˊga dᴀˊñᴀłan îˊsîn. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan k̲igw xajuwáay g̲íi kʼyuwáay ʼll xasúugaangaan, kʼáagä dángahlan isán.
\eng Then she put the large (Saxidomus squalidus) and the small clams into a little basket.
\src 0353:16

\cit 003:015
\swa Wᴀˊ-giên dᴀˊñᴀł lʼ qāˊgalgañan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan dángahl ʼll k̲áagalgaangaan.
\eng And she went up to the house with them.
\src 0353:17

\cit 003:016
\swa Gᴀm lʼ st!aˊdaᵋañgañan. 
\mod Gám ʼll stʼahdáaʼanggaangaan.
\eng It (the basket) was not full.
\src 0353:18

\cit 003:017
\swa Wᴀˊgiên tc!āˊanusi lʼ x̣ᴀˊîsigañan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan tsʼáanuus ii ʼll xa_isíigaangaan.
\eng And she put them into the fire.
\src 0353:19

\cit 003:018
\swa Lʼ djā ʟ!ao ʟīˊdᴀgwiᴀgan.
\mod ʼLl jáa tlʼaa uu tlíi daguyáagaan.
\eng His wife was strong.
\src 0353:20

\cit 003:019
\swa Lᴀ ʟ!ao ᵋagāˊlan. 
\mod ʼLáa tlʼaa uu g̲agáalaan.
\eng He, however, was weak.
\src 0353:21

\cit 003:020
\swa ᵋaˊlᴀnsʟasi giên ʟāˊ-lᴀñ xētgᵘ lʼ îˊsdagañan.
\mod g̲aalánsdlaas ii gyaan, tláalang x̲idgw ʼll isdagáangaan.
\eng When they were cooked, she set them before her husband.
\src 0353:22

\cit 003:021
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lʼ dōˊsi giên lʼ ʟᴀgudᴀˊnsi giên lʼ tāˊ-āgan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll dúus ii gyaan, ʼll tlagwdángs ii gyaan, ʼll táagaan.
\eng Then he took them, felt of them, and ate.
\src 0353:23

\cit 003:022
\swa Lʼ taˊᵋodjusi giên q!al lʼ djā gîn ᵋa-i îsdaˊs giên kiagᵃ lʼ îˊsdagañan. 
\mod ʼLl táa g̲ujúus ii gyaan, k̲ʼál ʼll jáa gin g̲íi isdáas gyaan, kyáaga ʼll isdagáangaan.
\eng After he had eaten all, his wife put the shells into something and set them outside.
\src 0353:24

\cit 003:023
\swa Sîˊñias giên ʟāˊlᴀñ ga ᵋᴀnʟ̣ îˊsdagīs stʼ lʼ tēˊ-k!wᴀnsʟgañan.
\mod Sángyaas gyaan tláalang gä g̲ándl isdä gíis sdä, ʼll tíi_kʼwánsdlagaangaan.
\eng When evening came, and she had given her husband water, they went to bed.
\src 0353:25

!! Swanton page 94 = 354

\cit 003:024
\swa Wᴀˊgiên tc!āˊanuwē la q!ātgᵘx̣aˊodᵋōgañan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan tsʼáanuwaay ʼláa k̲ʼadgw xáwdaʼugaangaan.
\eng And there was a little fire in front of them.
\src 0354:01

\cit 003:025
\swa Wᴀˊdaalēkᵘ lʼ tīˊyañᵋū qaod saˊnʟ̣ans giên qēˊgu tc!îˊqōna lʼ untcīˊidañan.
\mod ʼWáa daalíigw ʼll tíiyaangʼuu k̲áwd, sáandlaans gyaan, k̲igw cha_k̲úunaa ʼll ún_chiidáangaan.
\eng Next day, after they had lain abed for a while, and morning had dawned, she put a large basket on her back.
\src 0354:02

\cit 003:026
\swa Q!oˊdju lʼ qēx̣uˊstᴀ ᵋᴀn lʼ īˊdjañan. 
\mod k̲ʼúujuu ʼll k̲íi xúusdä g̲an ʼll íijaangaan.
\eng She went to find decayed bark on rotten trees.
\src 0354:03

\cit 003:027
\swa Lʼ staˊdasi giên lʼ uˊntciîdañan. 
\mod ʼLl stahdáas ii gyaan, ʼll ún_chiidáangaan.
\eng When it (the basket) was full, she put it on her back.
\src 0353:04

\cit 003:028
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lʼ qāˊʟ!agañan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll k̲áatlʼaagaangaan.
\eng Then she came home.
\src 0354:05

\cit 003:029
\swa Wᴀˊgiên sîˊñias giên lʼ tēˊsʟaᵋōgañan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan sángyaas gyaan, ʼll tíisdläʼugaangaan.
\eng And at evening they went to bed.
\src 0354:06

\cit 003:030
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lʼ tēˊyañwas ʟ̣ū hîn djaˊᵋᴀñ lʼ sūˊdaian, “Dᴀñ wāˊnasᵋaˊs ʟ̣ū āˊdjgui ʟ! gwāˊsañgᵃ. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll tíiyaangʼwaas dluu, hín jáaʼang ʼll súudaayaan, "Dáng ʼwáanaasʼaas dluu, áajgwii tlʼ gwáasaanggaa.
\eng And after they had gone to bed, he said to his wife, "When you go after clams, look for something over there" (indicating the direction with his hand).
\src 0353:07

\cit 003:031
\swa Āˊdjgui hᴀn îsîˊn ʟ! gwāˊsañgī-īga.” 
\mod Áajgwii hánïsan tlʼ gwáasaang gíigaa.
\eng "Also keep looking for something over there."
\src 0354:08

\cit 003:032
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lʼ wāˊnasᵋaian.
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll ʼwáanaasʼaayaan.
\eng Then she went for clams.
\src 0354:09

\cit 003:033
\swa Wᴀˊgiên la lʼ sūdaiˊan gîñaˊn āˊdjgui lʼ qêˊñgwañan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan gingáan áajgwii ʼll k̲éenggwaangaan.
\eng And she looked around where he had directed her.
\src 0354:10

\cit 003:034
\swa Āˊdjgui hᴀn îˊsîn lʼ qêˊñgañan. 
\mod Áajgwii hánïsan ʼll k̲éenggaangaan.
\eng She also looked in the other place.
\src 0354:11

\cit 003:035
\swa Waˊʟ̣u k!īwēˊ lʼ łᵋāˊ-igañan.
\mod ʼWáadluu kʼyuwáay ʼll hlg̲áaygaangaan.
\eng Then she dug the clams.
\src 0354:12

\cit 003:036
\swa Hawaˊn lʼ qêˊñgᴀndan x̣udj giaˊns lʼ qäˊñᴀn. 
\mod Hawáan ʼll k̲ínggan dáan, xúuj gyáangs ʼll k̲éengaan.
\eng As she was digging, she saw a grisly bear standing there.
\src 0354:13
\note Translation seems a bit off.

\cit 003:037
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ʟ!ao hit!ᴀˊn ʟāˊlᴀñ ᵋa lʼ kîˊndaian. 
\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu hatʼán tláalang g̲aa ʼll kíndaayaan.
\eng But then she told her husband.
\src 0354:14

\cit 003:038
\swa Lʼ qatc!aˊs ʟ̣ū, “Āˊdjgua x̣ūdj qāˊʟ!añgua,” hîn ʟāˊlᴀñ lʼ sūdaiˊan.
\mod ʼLl k̲atsʼáas dluu, "Áajgwaa xúuj k̲áatlʼaʼaang gwaa," hín tláalang ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng When she entered, she said to her husband, "Over yonder there is a grisly bear coming out of the woods."
\src 0354:15

\cit 003:039
\swa “La gu daˊhōñus.” 
\mod "ʼLáa gw dahúngʼus?"
\eng "Is it near?"
\src 0354:16

\cit 003:040
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lagᵃ lʼ āˊñan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼláa gä ʼll áangaan.
\eng She said it was.
\src 0354:17

\cit 003:041
\swa “ʟ̣djigao ł dīgᵃ îˊsdi,” hîn djaˊᵋᴀñ lʼ sūdaiˊan. 
\mod "Dlajgáaw hl díi gä isdíi," hín jáaʼang ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng "Give me a belt," he said to his wife.
\src 0354:18

\cit 003:042
\swa Waˊʟ̣u hit!ᴀˊn qwaˊa-i lagᵃ lʼ djā îsdaˊs ʟ̣ū ᵋᴀñ lʼ ʟ̣ˊdjigusʟaian.
\mod ʼWáadluu hatʼán k̲wáay ʼláa gä ʼll jáa isdáas dluu, áng ʼll dlajgusdláayaan.
\eng And when she had given him a piece of cord, he girded himself.
\src 0354:19

\cit 003:043
\swa “Łᵋēˊdē ł dīgᵃ dīˊna îˊsda tc!īˊdalᴀña-i hᴀn îˊsîn,” hîn djāˊᵋᴀñ lʼ sūdaiˊan.
\mod "Hlg̲íidaay hl díi gä díinaa isdáa, tsʼatʼalangáay hánïsan," hín jáaʼang ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng "Give me my bow and arrows," he said to his wife.
\src 0354:20

\cit 003:044
\swa Wᴀˊgiên sa łᵋēˊdē lᵋāˊña idjaˊni. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan sáa hlg̲íidaay ʼláangaa ijáan ii.
\eng His bow was hanging up.
\src 0354:21

\cit 003:045
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lʼ djā dᴀñxāˊst!aalan giên lagᵃ lʼ îˊsdaian. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll jáa dáng_x̲astʼáalaan gyaan, ʼláa gä ʼll isdáayaan.
\eng And when his wife had pulled it down, she gave it to him.
\src 0354:22

\cit 003:046
\swa Wᴀˊgiên “Tc!îˊdalᴀñē sq!aˊstᴀñ hīk!aˊ ł hᴀˊłgwīgᵃ îˊsda,” hîn djāˊᵋᴀñ lʼ sūdaiˊan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan, "Tsʼatʼalangáay sk̲ʼáasdang hikʼáa hl hahlgwíi gä isdáa," hín jáaʼang ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng Then he said to his wife, "Bring me two arrows only."
\src 0354:23

\cit 003:047
\swa Wᴀˊgiên sq!aˊstᴀñ lagᵃ lʼ xāˊsʟaian. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan sk̲ʼáasdang ʼláa gä ʼll x̲asdláayaan.
\eng And she handed him two.
\src 0354:24

\cit 003:048
\swa “Ha-i gᴀm gᵘ laᵋa dᴀñ ł ᵋᴀˊlʟ̣te-îtłiñan,” hîn ʟāˊlᴀñ lʼ sūdaiˊan. 
\mod "Háay gám gw ʼláa g̲áadang Hl g̲ál_dladíid hlangaan," hín tláalang ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng "Now shall I lead you?" she said to her husband.
\src 0354:25

\cit 003:049
\swa “Ditᴀgwaˊ-i-i ł dī ᵋᴀˊlʟ̣dalan.
\mod "Didgwáay hl díi g̲ál_dladáalaan.
\eng "Lead me to the woods.
\src 0354:26

\cit 003:050
\swa Sq!āˊño îsîˊn ł wᴀ îñgᵘ tc!îˊdalᴀña-i sq!ᴀˊłan ᵋᴀn t!ᴀˊsq!aʟañ kun sq!astᴀˊnsîñ ᴀ,” hîn djāˊᵋāñ lʼ sūdaiˊan. 
\mod Sk̲ʼáangw isán hl ʼwáa ínggw tsʼatʼalangáay sk̲ʼahláan g̲an tʼa_sk̲ʼáalaang, kún sk̲ʼáa stánsang aa," hín jáaʼang ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng Also break a two-pointed stick on which to place the arrows," he said to his wife.
\src 0354:27
\note Translation seems off here.

\cit 003:051
\swa Wᴀˊgiên hit!ᴀˊn qēˊdē qāˊłgut la lʼ îˊsdalᵋawan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan hatʼán k̲íidaay k̲áahlguud ʼláa ʼll isdáalʼaawaan.
\eng Then they went together into the woods.
\src 0354:28

\cit 003:052
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lʼ giaˊns la dīˊtgu lʼ îˊsʟ!aᵋawan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll gyáangs ʼláa didgw ʼll istlʼáaʼaawaan.
\eng And they came behind the place where it (the bear) stood.
\src 0354:29

\cit 003:053
\swa Wᴀgiêˊn gᵘ lʼ ʟ!aˊoᵋawan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan gu ʼll tlʼáawʼaawaan.
\eng And they sat down there.
\src 0354:30


!! Swanton page 95 = 355

\cit 003:054
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ʟ!ao hîn djāˊᵋᴀñ lʼ sūdaiˊan “Sq!āˊñwē ł aʟ̣n gīˊtc!a. 
\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu hín jáaʼang ʼll súudaayaan, "Sk̲ʼáangwaay hl áatlʼan gíitsʼaa.
\eng But then he said to his wife, "Push the stick down here.
\src 0355:01

\cit 003:055
\swa Lʼ giêˊns yä ł îˊsda,” hîn djāˊᵋᴀñ lʼ sūdaiˊan. 
\mod ʼLl gyáangs yáa hl isdáa," hín jáaʼang ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng Place it directly opposite the place where it is standing."
\src 0355:02

\cit 003:056
\swa Wᴀˊgiên anᴀˊñ īˊłiña q!ēˊyas łᵋēˊdē ᴀˊñᵋa lʼ xagāˊñan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan a nang íihlangaa k̲ʼayáas angáa ʼll x̲áagaangaan.
\eng And the old man held his bow in his hands.
\src 0355:03

\cit 003:057
\swa Waˊʟ̣u hit!ᴀˊn “Aˊdji îñgᵘ ł tc!îˊdalᴀña-i sq!ᴀˊłina la yä ł kuˊndjudañ,” hîn djāˊᵋᴀñ lʼ sūdaiˊan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu hatʼán, "Áajii ínggw hl tsʼatʼalangáay sk̲ʼahlänáa ʼláa yáa hl kúnjuudaang," hín jáaʼang ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng Then he said to his wife, "Aim the arrow straight at it between the two points."
\src 0355:04

\cit 003:058
\swa Wᴀˊgiên wᴀ îñgᵘ lʼ sq!ᴀˊłnagan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼwáa ínggw ʼll sk̲ʼahlänáagaan.
\eng And she put it between them.
\src 0355:05

\cit 003:059
\swa Waˊʟ̣u hit!ᴀˊn dᴀ lʼ dᴀˊnteitsi ʟ̣ū wᴀˊgiên “Waiˊya-a lᵋāˊña îˊsîn lagᵃ lʼ sūs ʟ̣ū lʼ ʟîˊk!ataian.
\mod ʼWáadluu hatʼán dä ʼll dáng tíids ii dluu, ʼwáagyaan, "Wáay yáa ʼláangaa isán ʼláa gä ʼll súus dluu, ʼll tla_kʼáatʼaayaan.
\eng After he had drawn the bowstring, and she had said to him, "It is aimed exactly right," he let it go.
\src 0355:06
\note Not clear where the quoted material ends -- missing closing quote in Swanton original

\cit 003:060
\swa Wᴀˊgiên q!āˊtgui lʼ ᵋāˊsᴀgᴀñasᵋaian.
\mod ʼWáagyaan k̲ʼadgwíi ʼll g̲aasagangaasʼaayaan
\eng Then (the bear) ran towards the sea.
\src 0355:07

\cit 003:061
\swa Lʼ ʟik!āˊtas ʟ̣ū lʼ ᵋei āˊdawasi ʟ̣ū, “Hū dī īnaˊdals ʟ̣ū x̣ūˊᴀdj ł tc!igīˊni gîñaˊn ł ᵋāˊndᴀñgᴀñ,” hîn lʼ sāˊwan. 
\mod ʼLl tla_kʼáatʼaas dluu, ʼll g̲íi áadaawaas ii dluu, "Húu! Díi ináadaals dluu xúuwajii Hl tsʼagíinii gingáan Hl g̲áandanggang," hín ʼll sáawaan.
\eng When he let go, (the arrow) went through it, and he said, "Hū! I feel as I used to when I shot a grisly bear in my youth."
\src 0355:08

\cit 003:062
\swa “Hao lᴀ  dᴀñ ᵋaˊʟ̣ao stᴀʼdāˊlgᴀñ. 
\mod "Húu ʼláa dáng g̲aatlʼaaw stahdáalgang.
\eng His wife said to him, "You missed it, bad one!
\src 0355:09

\cit 003:063
\swa Hao lʼ ᵋāˊtagᴀlgᴀña,” hîn lʼ djā lʼ sūdaiˊan. 
\mod Húu ʼll g̲áataagalgangaa," hín ʼll jáa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng It ran into the woods."
\src 0355:10

\cit 003:064
\swa La lʼ x̣îˊᵋot!ᴀłdaian. 
\mod ʼLáa ʼll xi_g̲utʼahldáayaan.
\eng She pushed him down.
\src 0355:11

\cit 003:065
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lʼ ʟ̣āˊst!aian.
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll dláastʼaayaan.
\eng Then he fell on his back.
\src 0355:12

\cit 003:066
\swa Wᴀˊgien ʟa-aˊ gᵘ lʼ ʟ̣ūˊdagañan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan tlʼaa gu ʼll dlúudägaangaan.
\eng And he lay there a long time.
\src 0355:13

\cit 003:067
\swa ʟāˊlᴀñ lʼ gîñqōˊnañan. 
\mod Tláalang ʼll gíng_k̲úunaangaan.
\eng She had lied to her husband.
\src 0355:14

\cit 003:068
\swa Gᵘ lʼ ʟ̣ūˊdasi
t!ał lʼ djā la qasᵋaiˊan. 
\mod Gu ʼll dlúudaas ii tʼáahl, ʼll jáa ʼláa k̲áasʼaayaan.
\eng While he lay there, his wife went down to it.
\src 0355:15

\cit 003:069
\swa Xūˊᴀdji k!ōˊt!alani. 
\mod Xúuwajii kʼutʼáalaan ii.
\eng The grisly bear was dead.
\src 0355:16

\cit 003:070
\swa Waˊʟ̣u lʼ ʟāl q!ałūˊs ʟ̣ū, lagᵃ lʼ kīˊagañîdan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu ʼll tláal k̲ʼáahluus dluu, ʼláa gä ʼll kyáagaangʼidaan.
\eng And when her husband got up he began to call to her.
\src 0355:17

\cit 003:071
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lagᵃ lʼ kiaˊgans giên gᴀm lʼ añsᵋwāˊnᴀñᵋañan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼláa gä ʼll kyáagangs gyaan, gám ʼll áng sg̲wáanangʼaangaan.
\eng And when he called to her, she did not reply.
\src 0355:18

\cit 003:072
\swa ʟ̣āˊlᴀñ gᵃ lʼ gwaˊgālan. 
\mod Tláalang gä ʼll gwáagaalaan.
\eng She abandoned her husband.
\src 0355:19

\cit 003:073
\swa Waˊʟ̣u la lʼ q!eˊitʟ̣sʟas ʟ̣ū nagᵃ la lʼ q!ēˊłᴀñîdan.
\mod ʼWáadluu ʼláa ʼll k̲ʼíid dlasdláas dluu, náagä ʼláa ʼll k̲ʼíihlangidaan.
\eng And after she had cut it up, she began to bring it into the house.
\src 0355:20

\cit 003:074
\swa La lʼ uˊnłᴀñgañan. 
\mod ʼLáa ʼll ún_hlánggaangaan
\eng She put it on her back.
\src 0355:21

\cit 003:075
\swa Wᴀˊk!iał lʼ ʟāl lagᵃ kiäˊgañgañan. 
\mod ʼWáakʼyaahl ʼll tláal ʼláa gä kyáagaanggaangaan.
\eng Meanwhile her husband was calling to her.
\src 0355:22
\note Original English for these last two Haida lines: While she was putting it on her back, her husband was calling to her.

\cit 003:076
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lêˊstᴀ kīˊlᴀñ lʼ sᵋāˊlgañan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼléesdä kíilang ʼll sg̲álgaangaan.
\eng And she hid her voice from him.
\src 0355:23

\cit 003:077
\swa Wᴀˊgiên nagᵃ lᵋāˊña lʼ ᵋoˊstᴀtc!adaiani.
\mod ʼWáagyaan náagä ʼláangaa ʼll g̲usdatsʼädáayaan ii.
\eng Then she brought all of the meat into the house.
\src 0355:24

\cit 003:078
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lʼ ʟāl lagᵃ kiāˊ-āgañgañgan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll tláal ʼláa gä kyáagaanggaangaan.
\eng And her husband called about for her.
\src 0355:25

\cit 003:079
\swa Wᴀˊgiên sîˊñiaiyᴀn. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan sángyaayaan.
\eng Then evening came.
\src 0355:26

\cit 003:080
\swa Wᴀgiêˊn gᵘ lʼ q!ᴀo qaod ᵋāˊlga-iᵋēłs lʼ ᵋāˊndañan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan gu ʼll k̲ʼáw k̲áwd, g̲áalgeeʼeehls ʼll g̲áandaangaan.
\eng And after he had sat there for a while, he perceived that night had come on.
\src 0355:27

\cit 003:081
\swa Waˊʟ̣u hit!ᴀˊn ʟᴀq!oaˊnᴀn lʼ ʟūgwāˊñedan.
\mod ʼWáadluu hatʼán tlak̲ʼwáanaan ʼll tlúu_gwáangiidaan.
\eng Then he crept about in the woods.
\src 0355:28
\note Translation??

\cit 003:082
\swa Wᴀˊgiên ʟan lʼ kiäˊgañan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan tláan ʼll kyáagaangaan.
\eng And he stopped calling.
\src 0355:29

\cit 003:083
\swa Hawaˊn lʼ ʟiᵋūñgwᴀˊñgᴀndan k!iūˊ ᵋᴀn lʼ ʟūˊʟ!agan.
\mod Hawáan ʼll tlaʼúnggwaanggan dáan, kʼyúu g̲an ʼll tlúutlʼaagaan.
\eng While he was creeping about, he crept to a trail.
\src 0355:30

\cit 003:084
\swa Łᵋēˊdē giagᵘ la lʼ tc!îˊgangwan lʼ dāˊñani. 
\mod Hlg̲íidaay gyáagw ʼláa ʼll tsʼagángwaan ʼll dáangaan ii.
\eng He left the bow where he had shot.
\src 0355:31

\cit 003:085
\swa Waˊʟ̣u k!iwēˊ gut lʼ ʟ!ūˊwe-îdani.
\mod ʼWáadluu kʼyuwáay gúud ʼll tlʼúuweeʼidaan ii.
\eng Then he began to crawl along the trail.
\src 0355:32

\cit 003:086
\swa Dītgᵃ lʼ îs ᵋᴀn gᴀm lʼ uˊnsᴀdaᵋañan.
\mod Didgä ʼll is g̲an, gám ʼll únsadaaʼaangaan.
\eng He did not know that he was crawling into the woods.
\src 0355:33

!! Swanton page 96 = 356

\cit 003:087
\swa Hawaˊn lʼ ʟ̣ūˊgᴀndan tcān gᵃ lʼ sʟ!ē lᵋāˊña xawīˊgaian. 
\mod Hawáan ʼll dlúugan dáan, cháan gä ʼll stláay ʼláangaa x̲awíigaayaan.
\eng After he had crept along for a while, his hands went into water.
\src 0356:01

\cit 003:088

\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll k̲ugwdáangaan.
\eng And he tasted it.
\src 0356:02

\cit 003:089

\mod "Táng uu íisang," ʼll gudáangaan.
\eng "It is salt water," he thought.
\src 0356:03
\note Either a weird typo for íijang, or one of those surmising-hypothetical-deductive suffixes

\cit 003:090
\swa Wᴀˊgiên ᵋᴀˊnʟ̣agan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan g̲ándlaagaan.
\eng And it was fresh water.
\src 0356:04

\cit 003:091

\eng Then he wanted to feel of it.
\src 0356:05

\cit 003:092

\mod Gin gyáang ʼll tlʼagwdaangaan.
\eng He crept to something standing (that is, a tree).
\src 0356:06

\cit 003:093

\mod ʼWáagyaan tlakʼáalaang ʼll g̲áandangs dluu, gu ʼll k̲ʼáawaan.
\eng And when he felt himself under the shelter of its branches, he sat down there.
\src 0356:07

\cit 003:094

\mod Áa uu tlíis ii dluu, ʼll sg̲áyhlaayaan.
\eng At this time he wept.
\src 0356:08

\cit 003:095

\mod ʼLl sg̲áyhlaas, ʼll sg̲áyhlaas.
\eng He wept, wept.
\src 0356:09

\cit 003:096

\mod ʼLl sg̲áyhlä k̲áwd, ʼll tíigaan.
\eng After he had wept for a while, he lay down.
\src 0356:10

\cit 003:097

\mod ʼLl tíigan dáan, íinggwaa g̲agwíi x̲itʼíid kíndaayaan.
\eng Just as he lay down, far away on the other side a bird called.
\src 0356:11

\cit 003:098

\mod Táadl uu sáawaan.
\eng It was a Loon that cried.
\src 0356:12

\cit 003:099

\mod ʼWáadluu súuwaay íiwaans ii ʼll g̲áandaangaan.
\eng Then he perceived that the lake was large.
\src 0356:13

\cit 003:100
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ᴀłdjīˊ lʼ gudᴀˊn-ndi qaod aāˊnan îsîˊn lʼ kîndaiˊan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu ahljíi ʼll gudándii k̲áwd, aʼáanaan isán ʼll kíndaayaan,
\eng And after he had listened for this for a while, it called nearer.
\src 0356:14

\cit 003:101

\mod ʼWáadluu ʼll dlúuwadaagan dáan ʼll x̲idgw gudangáagaan.
\eng And as he lay there it was heard below him.
\src 0356:15

\cit 003:102

\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll dlagadáajaan, ʼll x̲idgw aa.
\eng Then it came out of the water below him.
\src 0356:16
\note Interesting use of ʼll instead of ʼláa here.

\cit 003:103
\swa Waˊʟ̣u hîn anᴀˊñ xāˊdas tāˊʟ̣ē sūdaiˊan “Dīˊgu-ē ł qāˊʟ̣ī.” 
\mod ʼWáadluu hín a nang x̲aadáas táadlaay súudaayaan, "Díi gwee hl k̲áadlii."
\eng At that time the Loon said to this man, "Get on my back."
\src 0356:17

\cit 003:104

\eng And he crawled down to it.

\cit 003:105

\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼláa ʼll tlagwdánggaangaan.
\eng And he felt of it.
\src 0356:19

\cit 003:106
\swa “Lʼ tc!ūˊdju-idᴀn.  
\mod "ʼLl tsʼúujuuʼiidang.
\eng "It is too small.
\src 0356:20

\cit 003:107
\swa Laᵋa ł t!ᴀˊdjaʟ̣adaasañ,” hîn lʼ gudāˊñan.
\mod ʼLáa g̲aa Hl tʼajáadlaadaaäsaang," hín ʼll gudáangaan.
\eng I shall sink on it," he thought.
\src 0353:21
\note Original English for the last two lines: He thought, "It is too small. I shall sink on it."

\cit 003:108

\mod ʼWáadluu áa nang x̲aadáas gudangáay ʼll k̲éenggaangaan.
\eng Then it saw this person's thought.
\src 0353:22

\cit 003:109
\swa Waˊʟ̣u “Gaˊano gᴀm tcān dī dᴀñ tᴀˊʟ̣łᴀgañasañ.
\mod ʼWáadluu, "Gáaʼanuu, gám cháan díi dáng ta_dlahlagáangaasaang.
\eng Then, "No, indeed! You will not sink under water with me.
\src 0356:23

\cit 003:110

\mod k̲áadlii hlaa," hín tadláay sáawaan. 
\eng Get upon me," the Loon said.
\src 0356:24
\note Original English for the last two lines: Then the Loon said, "No, indeed! You will not sink under water with me. Get upon me."

\cit 003:111
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ʟ!ao hao îsîˊn la lʼ ʟᴀgudāˊñgaian.
\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu háwïsan ʼláa ʼll tlagwdáangaayaan.
\eng So he felt of it again.
\src 0356:25

\cit 003:112

\mod ʼWáagyaan gám ʼll cháadlaadaaʼaangaan.
\eng And it did not sink.

\cit 003:114

\mod Tlúu íiwaan gingáan ʼll tláatsʼägaagaan.
\eng It was as strong as a big canoe.
\src 0356:28

\cit 003:115

\mod ʼWáagyaan ínggw ʼll k̲ʼáawaan.
\eng And he sat upon it.
\src 0356:29

\cit 003:116

\mod "Díi tʼáawun k̲áahlii yáa hl cháanansgad," hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng "Put your head under my feathers," it said to him.
\src 0356:30

\cit 003:117

\eng And he put his head under the feathers.
\src 0356:31

\cit 003:118

\mod "Díi gä hl agáng sk̲ʼáwdlätʼas íiwaanan," hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng "Put your arms around me," it said to him.
\src 0356:32

\cit 003:119

\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼláa gä agáng ʼll sk̲ʼáwdläsgaadaan.
\eng And he put his arms around it.
\src 0356:33

\cit 003:120
\swa “Dᴀñ qagᴀˊndjuᵋaˊʼgałs ʟ̣ū ł dī q!ᴀl xāˊłdañ,” hîn la lʼ kîˊñgugᴀnʟdjawan.
\mod "Dáng k̲agánjuu g̲ahgahls dluu hl, díi k̲ʼál x̲áahldaang," hín ʼláa ʼll kínggwgang dläjáawaan.
\eng It instructed him, (saying,) "When your throat gets tired, scratch my skin."
\src 0356:34

\cit 003:121
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ʟ!ao lʼ kîˊndaiᴀn.  
\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu ʼll kíndaayaan.
\eng But then it cried.
\src 0356:35

\cit 003:122

\mod "Wáa háw!" hín ʼll kíndaa dlajáawaan.
\eng "Wa-a-a hō!" it cried.
\src 0356:36

\cit 003:123

\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll g̲áatlʼaagaan.
\eng And it dived.
\src 0356:37

\cit 003:124
\swa Wᴀˊgiên sūˊwē yūˊᴀnsi k!iên ᵋadōˊ lᴀ dᴀˊñᴀł lʼ gīˊgan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan suwáay íiwaans ii kʼyaan, g̲adúu ʼláa dángahl ʼll gíigaan.
\eng And although the lake was big, it swam around with him.
\src 0356:38

!! Swanton page 97 = 357

\cit 003:125
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lʼ gīs, lʼ gīs, lʼ gīs. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll gíis, ʼll gíis, ʼll gíis.
\eng And it swam, it swam, it swam-m.
\src 0357:01

\cit 003:126
\swa Giaˊgᵘ lʼ q!aˊowaiyan gᵘ lᴀ dᴀˊñᴀł lˊ ʟ̣îˊgadadjan. 
\mod Gyáagw ʼll k̲ʼáwaayaan gw ʼláa dángahl ʼll dlagáadaajaan.
\eng It came out with him where the man had been sitting.
\src 0357:02

\cit 003:127
\swa Gᴀm la lʼ xāˊłdaᵋañan. 
\mod Gám ʼláa ʼll x̲áahldäʼaangaan.
\eng He did not scratch it.
\src 0357:03

\cit 003:128
\swa Lʼ qagᴀˊndju hawᴀˊn ʟāˊdjigagān.
\mod ʼLl k̲agánjuu hawáan tláatsʼägaagaan.
\eng His throat was still strong.
\src 0357:04

\cit 003:129
\swa Lʼ ʟ̣îˊgadadjan ʟ̣ū hîn la lʼ sūdaiˊan, “K!wē ł gᴀm qeˊîłᵋañ.” 
\mod ʼLl dlagáadaajaan dluu, hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan, "Kʼwáay hl gám k̲éehläʼang."
\eng When it came out, it said to him, "Don't look up."
\src 0357:05

\cit 003:130
\swa Wᴀgîñaˊn ū lʼ ᵋedaˊn. 
\mod ʼWáa gingáan uu ʼll g̲éedaan.
\eng He obeyed.
\src 0357:06

\cit 003:131
\swa Waˊʟ̣u haˊoîsîn lᴀ dᴀˊñᴀł lʼ ᵋāˊʟaᵋᴀñqasagan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu háwsan ʼláa dángahl ʼll g̲áadlaaʼang k̲asaʼáayaan.
\eng Then it again went down with him.
\src 0357:07
\note Translation seems off.  Also, we changed -gaan to -yaan here to make the FST happy, but we should update.

\cit 003:132
\swa Taʟ̣ēˊ qagᴀˊndju dᴀˊ-
guiᵋēłs ʟ̣ū haˊoîsîn lʼ kîˊndaian. 
\mod Tadláay k̲aǵanjuu daguyéehls dluu, háwsan ʼll kíndaayaan.
\eng When the Loon's throat became strong, it called again.
\src 0357:08

\cit 003:133
\swa “Wa-a
hao!” hîn lʼ kîñāˊñan. 
\mod "Wáa háw!" hín ʼll kingáangaan.
\eng "Wa-a-a ho!" it called.
\src 0357:09

\cit 003:134
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ʟ!ao hit!ᴀˊn lʼ ᵋāˊʟ!agan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu hatʼán ʼll g̲áatlʼaagaan.
\eng At once it dived.
\src 0357:10

\cit 003:135
\swa Waˊʟ̣u haˊoîsîn sūwēˊ ᵋadōˊ la dᴀˊñᴀł lʼ gaˊ-idᴀn. 
\mod ʼWáadluu háwsan suwáay g̲adúu ʼláa dángahl ʼll gáaydaan.
\eng Then it again swam around the lake with him.
\src 0357:11

\cit 003:136
\swa Wᴀˊgiên haˊoîsîn îʼsîn lʼ q!awaiˊan xetgᵘ lʼ ʟ̣gadadjan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan háwsan isán ʼll k̲ʼáwaayaan x̲idgw ʼll dlagáadaajaan.
\eng And again it came below the place where he had been sitting.
\src 0357:12

\cit 003:137
\swa “Ha-i qeˊiła ła,” hîn la lʼ sudaiˊan. 
\mod "Háay k̲éehlaa hlaa," hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng "Now look up," it said to him.
\src 0357:13

\cit 003:138
\swa Waˊʟ̣u lʼ ᵋᴀˊnstᴀ ʟ!aˊgan giên lʼ qeˊiʟ!agan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu ʼll g̲ánsdä tlʼáagaan gyaan ʼll k̲éetlʼaagaan.
\eng Then he took his head out and tried to open his eyes.
\src 0357:14

\cit 003:139
\swa Wᴀˊgiên hîn la lʼ sudaiˊan “Wāˊdjgua ʟᴀgᵃ kuˊndjus ł qêˊnʟagan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan, "Wáajgwaa tlagä kúnjuus hl k̲íng tláagaan."
\eng And it said to him, "Look first at that point of land yonder."
\src 0357:15

\cit 003:140
\swa Waˊʟ̣u lagᵃ lʼ qēˊyaiyan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu ʼláa gä ʼll k̲íiyaayaan.
\eng Then he looked at it.
\src 0357:16

\cit 003:141
\swa Wᴀˊgiên la xetīˊt lʼ qêˊnsgiênsᵋwāˊnañan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼláa x̲itʼíid ʼll k̲ínsgyaan sg̲wáanaangaan.
\eng And he saw through under it.
\src 0357:17

\cit 003:142
\swa “U ʟdao q!aos ł qêñ. 
\mod "Úu tlatʼaʼáaw k̲ʼáaws hl k̲íng.
\eng "Look at those mountains.
\src 0357:18

\cit 003:143
\swa Gut gîn isīˊ îˊsîn ł qêñ,” hîn la lʼ sudaiˊan. 
\mod Gúud gin is íi isán hl k̲íng," hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng Look at the things upon them," it said to him.
\src 0357:19

\cit 003:144
\swa Wᴀˊgîñan gui lʼ qêns ʟ̣ū gîn teˊiga gut îˊsi lʼ qêˊñgañan.
\mod ʼWáa gingáan gwíi ʼll k̲íngs dluu, gin tíigaa gúud is íi ʼll k̲ínggaangaan.
\eng And when he looked towards them, he saw the animals upon them.
\src 0357:20

\cit 003:145
\swa X̣ūˊᴀdj îˊsgiên tān îˊsîn īdjāˊñan. 
\mod Xúuwajii isgyáan táan isán ijáangaan.
\eng There were grisly bears and black bears.
\src 0357:21

\cit 003:146
\swa Mᴀt gia îˊsîn īdjāˊñan. 
\mod Madgyáa isán ijáangaan.
\eng There were also mountain-goats.
\src 0357:22
\note Translation seems off.

\cit 003:147
\swa K!ūˊ gia îsîˊn.
\mod Kʼúugyaa isán.
\eng Marten, too.
\src 0357:23
\note Original English translation of the last two lines: There were also mountain-goats and marten.

\cit 003:148
\swa Wāˊdji gîn teˊigas gᵘ dᴀñ qêñ,” hîn la lʼ sudaiˊan. 
\mod "Wáajii gin tíigaas gw dáng k̲íng?" hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng "Do you see those animals there?" it said to him.
\src 0357:24
\note Swanton original is missing the open quote.

\cit 003:149
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lʼ qêˊñᴀñ lʼ sāˊwani.
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll k̲íngang ʼll sáawaan ii.
\eng And he said he saw them.
\src 0357:25
\note Nice zero-pronoun non-3pl object

\cit 003:150
\swa Wᴀg̣iêˊn hawaˊn lᴀˊgua lʼ tc!āˊ-añgañan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan hawáan ʼláa gwaa ʼll tsʼáa_ánggaangaan.
\eng And he was still sitting upon (the Loon).
\src 0357:26

\cit 003:151
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ʟ!ao hit!ᴀˊn la lʼ qāˊᴀłālan.
\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu hatʼán ʼláa ʼll k̲áaʼahlaalaan.
\eng Then, however, it told him to get off.
\src 0357:27

\cit 003:152
\swa “Ha-i qāˊᴀła,” hîn la lʼ sudaiˊan. 
\mod "Háay k̲áaʼahlaa," hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng "Now get off," it said to him.
\src 0357:28
\note Interesting lack of the imperative clitic after a verb ending in -hlaa.

\cit 003:153
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ʟ!ao lêˊstᴀ lʼ qaaˊlan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼ aa uu ʼléesdä ʼll k̲áaʼaalaan.
\eng At once he got off.
\src 0357:29

\cit 003:154
\swa Lʼ qaˊalan ʟ̣ū hîn la lʼ sudaiˊan, “K!wai ł haoʟ̣n q!ao dᴀñ ł kîˊñgugᴀñē ᵋᴀn ᴀ.” 
\mod ʼLl k̲áaʼaalaan dluu, hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan, "Kʼwáay hl húutlʼan k̲ʼáawdang, Hl kínggwgangee g̲an aa.
\eng When he got off, it said to him, "Sit there, so that I may give you directions."
\src 0357:30

\cit 003:155
\swa Wᴀˊgiên la îsîˊn gᵘ q!āˊwani. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼláa isán gu k̲ʼáawaan ii.
\eng And he sat in his former place.
\src 0357:31

\cit 003:156
\swa “Dᴀñ qāˊʟ̣!as ʟ̣ū ł na-i ᵋa ᴀˊñᵋa qāñ. 
\mod "Dáng k̲áatlʼaas dluu hl, náa g̲áa angáa káa.ang.
\eng "When you get home, go to your house.
\src 0357:32
\note Delayed imperative!

\cit 003:157
\swa Wᴀˊgiên x̣ūˊᴀdji qāˊdji lʼ gītc!āˊdᴀs ʟ̣ū hîn laˊᵋᴀn guˊdᴀñan, ‘Wēd ʟ!wāˊdji lʼ xᴀñgᵃ agᴀˊñ q!oq!ēˊsgada-añ.ʼ” 
\mod ʼWáagyaan xúuwajii k̲áajii ʼll gíi_tsʼáadaas dluu, hín ʼláa g̲an gudángang, 'Wéed tlʼawáajii ʼll x̲áng agáng k̲ʼu_k̲ʼíisgadaaʼaang.'"
\eng And when (your wife) cooks a grisly-bearhead, think as follows, 'Now let it bite her face.'"
\src 0357:33

\cit 003:158
\swa Wᴀgiêˊn lêˊstᴀ lʼ qāˊ-idan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼléesdä ʼll k̲áaydaan.
\eng And afterwards he started.
\src 0357:34

\cit 003:159
\swa “Hao qaˊ-it ła,” hîn la lʼ sudaiˊan.
\mod "Háaw, k̲áayd hlaa," hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng "Now go home," it said to him.
\src 0357:35

\cit 003:160
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lʼ qāˊʟ!as ʟ̣ū na-i ᵋa ᴀˊñᵋa lʼ qāˊgan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll k̲áatlʼaas dluu, náay g̲aa angáa ʼll k̲áagaan.
\eng And when he arrived, he went to his house.
\src 0357:36

\cit 003:161
\swa “Gᴀm djāˊᵋᴀñ agᴀˊñ ʟ! qêndāˊᵋañgᵃ, hîn la lʼ sudaiˊan. 
\mod "Gám jáaʼang agáng tlʼ k̲índäʼanggaa," hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng It had said to him, "Do not let your wife see you."
\src 0358:01

\cit 003:162

\mod ʼWáagyaan jáaʼang ʼll k̲íng k̲ʼuhltsʼägáangaan, tlʼadaláasii g̲áay aa.
\eng Then he looked stealthily at his wife through a small hole.
\src 0358:02

\cit 003:163

\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼláa g̲an ʼll guhlahlíidaan, ʼláa ʼll kínggwgaangaan gingáan aa.
\eng And he began to think about her as it had given him instructions.
\src 0358:03

\cit 003:164

\mod ʼWáagyaan hawáan, "Wéed tlʼaẃaajii ʼll x̲ánggä agáng k̲ʼu_k̲ʼíisgad," hín ʼll gudánggan dáan, xúuwajii k̲aj xáahldiidaan.

\cit 003:166

\eng Then she was rolling about.
\src 0358:06

\cit 003:167

\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu náagä jáaʼang ʼll dúu g̲atsʼáayaan.
\eng But then he ran into the house to his wife.
\src 0358:07

\cit 003:168
\swa Waˊʟ̣u djāˊᵋᴀñ lʼ gīˊdjigīłdas ʟ̣ū kiagᵃ lᴀ dᴀˊñᴀł lʼ ᵋāˊdagan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu jáaʼang ʼll gíijiigahldaas dluu, kyáagä ʼláa dángahl ʼll g̲áadaagaan.
\eng And having seized his wife, he ran outside with her.
\src 0358:08

\cit 003:169
\swa “Āˊdji ł dī xᴀñ stᴀ îˊsda,” hîn ʟāˊlᴀñ lʼ sudaiˊan. 
\mod "Áajii hl díi x̲áng sdä isdáa," hín tláalang ʼll śudaayaan.
\eng She said to her husband, "Take this from my face."
\src 0358:09

\cit 003:170
\swa Wᴀk!iêˊnᴀn la dᴀˊñᴀłan q!ᴀtgᵃ la lʼ k!āˊdasᵋaian. 
\mod ʼWáakʼyaanan ʼláa dángahlan k̲ʼadgä ʼláa ʼll kʼáatʼaasʼaayaan.
\eng Nevertheless he threw her on the beach with it.
\src 0358:10

\cit 003:171

\mod ʼLáa dángahl ʼll k̲ʼíi_yúunanggaan dáan, ʼll kʼutʼahldáaʼidaan.
\eng She rolled about with it. She soon died.
\src 0358:11
\note The English translation occurs in two sentences, but the Haida original has a comma.

\cit 003:172

\mod ʼWáagyaan hatʼán áajii angáa ʼll gíiyaalangʼidaan ii.
\eng And then he began to try the fat out of his bears.
\src 0358:12

\cit 003:173

\mod ʼWáagyaan tʼáwtʼ g̲aay táw angáa ʼll isdagáangaan.
\eng And he put the grease into boxes.
\src 0358:13

\cit 003:174

\mod ʼWáagyaan kyaʼáay isán ʼll kʼasdáaygahls dluu, náaguud ʼll kʼyáadaagaangaan.

\src 0358:14

\cit 003:175

\mod ʼLl xiláadaangaan.
\eng He dried them.
\src 0358:15

\cit 003:176

\mod ʼWáakʼyaahl x̲idgw ʼll tsʼáanuugaangaan.
\eng All that time he kept up a fire beneath.
\src 0358:16

\cit 003:177
\swa Tc!āˊanu ᵋᴀn ᴀˊñᵋa lʼ îˊsdaʟ!asi ʟ̣ū wᴀˊgiên łᵋēˊdē ᵋei gᴀm ᴀˊñᵋa lʼ q!eˊidᴀñgañan. 
\mod Tsʼáanuu g̲an angáa ʼll isdätlʼáas ii dluu, ʼwáagyaan hlg̲íidaay g̲íi gám angáa ʼll k̲ʼíidʼanggaangaan.
\eng When he brought the firewood for it, he did not forget his bow.
\src 0358:17

\cit 003:178

\mod ʼWáagyaan kyaʼáay dángahl táw dángahl ʼll g̲íihlgiidaa g̲ujáawaan.
\eng Then he finished preparing all of the meat and grease.
\src 0358:18

\cit 003:179

\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu tsʼatʼaláng ahl xúuwajii ʼll tsʼagáan angáa ʼll k̲éengaan.
\eng But at that time he saw the arrow with which he had shot the grisly bear.
\src 0358:19

\cit 003:180

\eng It was just above the place where he had lain down.
\src 0358:20

\cit 003:181
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ʟ!ao hit!ᴀˊn łᵋēˊdē ᵋa-i ᴀˊñᵋa lʼ q!eˊidan āˊnîs lʼ qêns ʟ̣ū ᴀ. 
\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu hatʼán hlg̲íidaay g̲aay angáa ʼll k̲ʼíidaan, áaniis ʼll k̲íngs dluu aa.
\eng When he saw it, however, he remembered his bow.
\src 0358:21

\cit 003:182
\swa Waˊʟ̣u hit!ᴀˊn ᴀˊñᵋa lʼ qêñᵋāˊgan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu hatʼán angáa ʼll k̲íng áagaan.
\eng Then he went to look for it.
\src 0358:22

\cit 003:183
\swa Wᴀˊgiên ᴀˊñᵋa lʼ qêñaˊs giên dīˊtgua tc!idalᴀñaˊ-i dᴀˊñᴀłan lᵋāˊña xagadāˊwan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan angáa ʼll k̲íng áas gyaan, didgwáa tsʼatʼalangáay dángahlaan ʼláangaa x̲áagädaawaan.
\eng And when he saw it, it was standing against something in the woods (a tree or stump), along with the arrows.
\src 0358:23

\cit 003:184
\swa Wᴀgiêˊn lʼ nagaˊn gᵘ dᴀˊñᴀł ᴀˊñᵋa lʼ qāˊʟ!agan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll náagaan gw dángahl angáa ʼll k̲áatlʼaagaan.

\mod ʼWáadluu ʼll k̲asáasdlaayaan.

\cit 003:186

\mod Sahlgáang ʼll sdíihlang_k̲asaʼáasdlaayaan.
\eng He was going to return (to the town).
\src 0358:26

\cit 003:187
\swa Wᴀˊgiên ʟūˊē hit!ᴀˊn tcāngᵃ ᴀˊñᵋa lʼ îsdaiˊan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan tluwáay hatʼán cháan gä angáa ʼll isdáayaan.
\eng Then he put his canoe into the water.
\src 0358:27

\cit 003:188
\swa Wᴀˊgiên kiēˊ k!iūˊ k!ūˊñat dᴀ lʼ îˊsdaʟ̣īs giên wᴀˊgui lʼ skiūˊᴀʟ̣īgan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan kyaʼáay kʼyuu kʼúungad dä ʼll isdáadliis gyaan, ʼwáa gwíi ʼll skyúuwadliigaan.
\eng And he laid boards in the bottom of the canoe for the meat, and placed the meat upon them.
\src 0358:28

\cit 003:189
\swa Wᴀˊgui lʼ îsdaᵋēˊłgīs ʟ̣ū dᴀˊñᴀł lʼ ʟuqaˊ-idan. 
\mod ʼWáa gwíi ʼll isdáa g̲íihlgiis dluu, dángahl ʼll tluu_k̲áaydaan.
\eng After he had laid it all upon them, he went away.
\src 0358:29

\cit 003:190
\swa Gᴀm łiñaˊn djāˊᵋᴀñ k!ōˊtgui lʼ qēyaᵋāˊñan. 
\mod Gám hlangáan jáaʼang kʼúud gwíi ʼll k̲íiyaaʼaangaan.
\eng He did not pay the least attention to his wife's dead body.
\src 0358:30

!! Swanton page 99 = 359

\cit 003:191
\swa Waˊʟ̣u lnagaˊ-i gᵘ lʼ ʟuqāˊʟ!agan.
\mod ʼWáadluu ʼlan-gáay gw ʼll tluu_k̲áatlʼaagaan.
\eng Then he came to the town.
\src 0359:01

\cit 003:192
\swa Lnagaˊ-i gᵘ lʼ ᵋāˊsgᴀts ʟ̣ū lnagaˊ-i xadēˊ waˊʟ̣uᴀn la ᵋoˊstᴀsᵋaian. 
\mod ʼLan-gáay gw ʼll g̲áasgads dluu, ʼlan-gáay x̲aadʼáay ʼwáadluwaan ʼláa g̲usdasʼáayaan.
\eng When he reached the town, all of the town-people came down to meet him.
\src 0359:02

\cit 003:193
\swa Laˊᴀł ʟ! guˊdᴀñē lāyuāˊnᴀn. 
\mod ʼLáa ahl tlʼ gudangáay ʼláa íiwaanaan.
\eng They were very glad to see him.
\src 0359:03

\cit 003:194
\swa Waˊʟ̣u āˊdji kiēˊ ʟ! waˊʟ̣uᴀn nagᵃ lā îˊsdagāñan.
\mod ʼWáadluu áajii kyaʼáay tlʼ ʼwáadluwaan náagä ʼláa isdägáangaan
\eng Then all brought his meat up to his house.
\src 0359:04

\cit 003:195
\swa Waˊʟ̣u lʼ qatc!aˊs ʟ̣ū hîn lʼ sāˊwan, “ʟ!aˊᵋᴀn ł ᵋāˊyiño āˊdji kiēˊ ʟ! tagaˊ-i ᵋᴀn ᴀ.” 
\mod ʼWáadluu ʼll k̲atsʼáas dluu, hín ʼll sáawaan, "Tlʼáa g̲an hl g̲áayangʼuu, áajii kyaʼáay tlʼ tagáay g̲an aa."
\eng After he had entered, he said, "Call the people to eat this meat."
\src 0359:05

\cit 003:196
\swa Wᴀˊgiên ʟ!aˊᵋᴀn ʟ! ᵋāˊ-iyañan ʟ̣ū īˊʟ!adē waˊʟ̣uᴀn ᵋoˊstᴀtc!aian. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan tlʼáa g̲an tlʼ g̲áayaangaan dluu, íitlʼaadée ʼwáadluwaan g̲usdatsʼáayaan.
\eng And when they called them, all the chiefs came in.
\src 0359:06

\cit 003:197
\swa “Haˊodji kiēˊ ł ʟ!aˊᵋᴀn ʟiñᵋalᴀˊñᵋo. 
\mod "Húujii kyaʼáay hl tlʼáa g̲an tláng_g̲alángʼuu.
\eng "Cook that meat for them.
\src 0359:07

\cit 003:198
\swa Xoaˊłdaᵋo ła.” 
\mod x̲wáahldäʼuu hlaa."
\eng Steam it."
\src 0359:08

\cit 003:199
\swa Hîn sk!ūˊlas lʼ sūˊdagañan.
\mod Hín skʼúulaas ʼll súudägaangaan.
\eng So he told the crowd of people.
\src 0359:09
\note Original English for the last three lines: He said to the crowd of people, "Cook that meat for them. Steam it."

\cit 003:200
\swa Wᴀˊgîñan ʟ! wᴀˊgan. 
\mod ʼWáa gingáan tlʼ ʼwáagaan.
\eng They did so.
\src 0359:10

\cit 003:201
\swa Tc!āˊanuē ᵋa-i waˊʟ̣u qwā ʟ! sîˊsᴀgañan. 
\mod Tsʼáanuwaay g̲áay ʼwáadluu k̲waa tlʼ sasägáaangaan.
\eng They put stones into the fire.
\src 0359:11

\cit 003:202
\swa K!īˊnsʟas ʟ̣ū hit!ᴀˊn t!ōˊtē tc!îˊstᴀñ waˊᵋᴀn ʟ! xāˊsʟsᵋaian. 
\mod Kʼíinäsdlaas dluu, hatʼán tʼáwtʼaay tsʼasdáng ʼwáa g̲an tlʼ x̲áasdläsʼaayaan.
\eng When they were hot, they brought out two boxes for it.
\src 0359:12

\cit 003:203
\swa Waˊʟ̣u hit!ᴀˊn ᵋᴀnʟ̣ āˊdji ᵋei ʟ! gīˊatagas ʟ̣ū kiēˊ wᵋei ʟ! îˊsdagi-edan.
\mod ʼWáadluu hatʼán g̲ándl áajii gíi tlʼ gíiyaadaagaas dluu, kyaʼáay ʼwée tlʼ isdägíiʼidaan.
\eng And after they had poured water into them, they began to put the meat in.
\src 0359:13

\cit 003:204
\swa Qwāˊa-i îˊsîn wᵋei ʟ! îsdaiˊan. 
\mod Kwaʼáay isán ʼwée tlʼ isdáayaan.
\eng They also put stones into them.
\src 0359:14

\cit 003:205
\swa Waˊʟ̣u sk!uˊlda qaod ᵋalᴀˊnsʟaiañi. 
\mod ʼWáadluu skʼáldaa k̲áwd, g̲aalánsdlaayaan ii.
\eng After they had boiled for a while, the (meat) was cooked.
\src 0359:15

\cit 003:206
\swa ᵋalᴀˊnsʟas ʟ̣ū k!eˊiłga ᵋaqōˊna ᵋa-i sʟāˊgwᴀl ᴀł ʟ! kîˊtîʟ!agañan. 
\mod g̲aalánsdlaas dluu, k̲íihlgaa g̲áa k̲úunaa g̲áay sdáagwaal ahl tlʼ ki_tíitlʼaagaangaan.
\eng When it was cooked, they put it into a large tray with spoons.
\src 0359:16

\cit 003:207
\swa Wᴀˊstō hit!ᴀˊn ʟ!a xetîˊt k!eˊiłga ʟ! îˊsteidᴀn. 
\mod ʼWáa sdä uu hatʼán tlʼáa x̲idíid kíihlgaa tlʼ istʼiʼíidaan.
\eng Then they put trays in front of them.
\src 0359:17

\cit 003:208
\swa Wᴀˊstō hit!ᴀˊn kiēˊ wᵋei ʟ! îˊsdadālani ᵋa-i dᴀˊñᴀłan îˊsîn. 
\mod ʼWáasdä uu hatʼán kyaʼáay ʼwée tlʼ isdädáalaan ii, g̲áay dángahlan iśan.
\eng Afterwards they put the meat into them with the fat.
\src 0359:18

\cit 003:209
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ʟ! tāˊgañan.
\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼ táagaangaan.
\eng Then they ate.
\src 0359:19

\cit 003:210
\swa ʟ! tagīˊgane ʟ̣ū “K!wē gᴀm qagałᵋāˊñᵋō. 
\mod Tlʼ táa gíigaan ii dluu, "Kʼwáay, gám k̲áagahlʼangʼuu.
\eng After they were through eating, "Do not go out.
\src 0359:20

\cit 003:211
\swa Dalᴀˊñ gᵃ ł giałaˊndaasañ,” hîn ʟ!a lʼ sūdaiˊan. 
\mod Daláng gä Hl gyaahlándaaäsaang," hín tlʼáa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng I will recount (my adventures) to you," he said to them.
\src 0359:21
\note Original English for the last two lines: After they were through eating, he said to them, "Do not go out. I will recount (my adventures) to you."

\cit 003:212
\swa “Āˊdji qaˊoq!alē ł ʟ!a giˊalaᵋo,” hîn łkiaˊgwē dᴀ ga îsgaˊ-i lʼ sudaiˊan. 
\mod "Áajii k̲áwk̲ʼalaay hl tlʼáa gíiyaalaaʼuu," hín hlkyáagwaay dä isgáay ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng He said to those around the door (the servants), "Carry home that which is left over."
\src 0359:22

\cit 003:213
\swa Wᴀˊgîñan k!eˊiłgē waˊʟ̣uᴀn ʟ!a ʟ! giˊalaᵋodjawan.
\mod ʼWáa gingáan k̲íihlgaay ʼwáadluwaan tlʼáa tlʼ gíiyaalaa g̲ujáawaan.
\eng So they took all of the trays to those at home.
\src 0359:23

\cit 003:214
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ʟ!ao hit!ᴀˊn ᴀłaˊñ lʼ gīˊałandāˊñqasāgan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu hatʼán ahláng ʼll gyaahlánda.ang_k̲asaʼáagaan.
\eng But then he was going to tell them about himself.
\src 0359:24

\cit 003:215

\mod ʼWáadluu ʼláa hl tlʼ kyáanaangaan.
\eng Then they questioned him.
\src 0359:25

\cit 003:216
\swa “Dā gᵘ a adjīˊ x̣ūˊᴀdji tīyaiˊya,” hîn lᴀ ʟ! sūdaiˊan. 
\mod "Dáa gw aa áajii xúuwajii tíiyaayaa?" hín ʼláa tlʼ súudaayaan.
\eng They said to him, "Did you kill this grisly bear?"
\src 0359:26

\cit 003:217
\swa Wᴀˊgiên “Añ” hîn lʼ sāˊwan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan, "Áang," hín ʼll sáawaan.
\eng And he said, "Yes."
\src 0353:27

\cit 003:218
\swa “Gasîˊno la dᴀñ teˊ-îdʟdjawañ,” hîn lᴀ ʟ! sūdaiˊan. 
\mod "Gasán uu ʼláa dáng tíidläjaawaan?" hín ʼláa tlʼ súudaayaan.
\eng They said to him, "How did you kill it?"
\src 0359:28

\cit 003:219
\swa Lʼ xᴀˊñqagāgan ᴀˊłū ʟᴀgᵘ la ʟ! sūdaiˊan. 
\mod ʼLl x̲áng k̲agáagaan ahl uu, tlagw ʼláa tlʼ súudaayaan. 
\eng They asked him how, because he had been blind.
\src 0359:29

\cit 003:220
\swa Wᴀˊgiên hîn lʼ sāˊwan, “Gaˊano dī djā-o ᵋa dī îˊsdagᴀni. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan hín ʼll sáawaan, "Gáaʼanuu, díi jáa uu g̲áa díi isdägán ii."
\eng And he said, "No, indeed! (I did not go by myself). My wife took me to it.
\src 0359:30

\cit 003:221

\mod ʼLáa didgw díi ʼll g̲ál_k̲áatlʼaagan.
\eng She led me behind it.
\src 0359:31

\cit 003:222

\cit 003:223

\cit 003:224

\cit 003:225

\cit 003:226

\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll kʼutʼáalaan," hín ʼll sáawaan.
\eng And it died." That is what he said.

\note Interesting switch back to Indirect Past.  Also awkwkard original English.

\cit 003:227
\swa “'Hao la dᴀñ ᵋaʟ̣aˊo stᴀʼdāˊlgᴀñgua,' hîn waˊʟ̣u dī djā dī sūˊdagᴀn. 
\mod "Háaw ʼláa dáng g̲adáaw sdadáalgang gwaa," hín ʼwáadluu díi jáa díi súudägan.
\eng "Then my wife said to me, 'You missed it, bad one!'
\src 0360:06

\cit 003:228

\mod Díi gä ʼláa ʼll k̲ʼúlgandaayaan gwaa.
\eng She concealed it (the truth) from me.
\src 0360:07

\cit 003:229

\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼláa gä Hl kyáagangs gyaan, gám díi gä ʼll áangʼanggiinii.
\eng And when I called to her, she did not answer me.
\src 0360:08

\cit 003:230

\eng Meanwhile she cut it up and carried it up to the house.
\src 0360:09

\cit 003:231
\swa Wᴀˊgiên giaˊgᵘ xūˊᴀdji ł tc!îˊgᴀn gᵘ ł q!aˊogᴀns stᴀ ʟᴀk!oaˊnᴀn ł ʟ!u-īˊdᴀn.

\eng And from sitting in the place where I had shot the bear I crept about in the woods.
\src 0360:10

\cit 003:232

\cit 003:233

\mod ʼWáagyaan kʼyuwáay gúud Hl tlʼúuwidan.
\eng And I crept along upon the trail.
\src 0360:12

\cit 003:234

\mod ʼWáadluu chaan gä díi stláay jahlagáas Hl g̲áandanggan.
\eng At that time I felt my hands go into water.
\src 0360:13

\cit 003:235
\swa Tᴀñ îˊsîn ł gudᴀˊns ʟ̣ū ł k!ōˊgudᴀñgᴀñ.
\mod Táng isán Hl gudángs dluu, Hl kʼugwdánggang.
\eng Since I thought it was sea-water, I tasted it.
\src 0360:14

\cit 003:236

\mod ʼWáagyaan g̲ándl íijang Hl tlagwdánggan ii, dlúuhlaa sg̲áyhläʼiidan.
\eng And when I knew it was fresh water, I began to weep.
\src 0360:15

\cit 003:237
\swa “Waˊʟ̣u adjīˊ djîˊngu hawaˊn ł ʟ̣udagᴀˊndan xetîˊt îˊngua ᵋaguiˊ kiñᴀˊns ł gudᴀˊñgᴀn. 
\mod ʼWáadluu áajii ján gw hawáan Hl dluudägán dáan, x̲idʼíid ínggw g̲agwíi kingáangs Hl gudánggan.
\eng "And while I was still lying beside it, I heard a bird call far away on the opposite side.
\src 0360:16

\cit 003:238
\swa Lʼ sūˊgᴀns stᴀ ᵋet qaod aaˊnᴀn îˊsîn lʼ kiñāˊñgᴀn. 
\mod ʼLl súugans sdä g̲id k̲áwd, aʼáanaan isán ʼll kingáanggan.
\eng After a while it began calling again near me.
\src 0360:17

\cit 003:239
\swa Wᴀˊstᴀ ᵋet qaod hawaˊn ł ʟ̣udᴀgᴀˊndan dī xetgᵘ lʼ ʟ̣îˊgudᴀs ł ᵋāˊndᴀñgan. 
\mod ʼWáa sdä g̲id k̲áwd, hawáan Hl dluudägán dáan, díi xidgw ʼll dlagwdáas Hl g̲áandanggan.
\eng After some time had passed, while I lay there, I perceived that it had come out below me.
\src 0360:18

\cit 003:240
\swa Waˊʟ̣u āˊdji xeˊtadē dī ᵋa kîłguˊlgᴀn ‘Dī gwe ł qāˊʟ̣ī,ʼ hîn dī lʼ sūˊdagᴀn. 
\mod ʼWáadluu áajii xidʼadáay díi g̲áa kihlgúlgan, 'Díi gwee hl k̲áadlii,' hín díi ʼll súudägan.
\eng Then this bird spoke to me. It said to me, 'Get upon me.'
\src 0360:19

\cit 003:241

\mod ʼWáagyaan Hl tlagwdángägan.

\src 0360:20

\cit 003:242

\eng And it was too small to get on.
\src 0353:21

\cit 003:243

\mod Ahljíihl uu díi hlg̲wáagaagan.

\src 0360:22

\cit 003:244
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ‘Gaˊano dīˊgwe ł qāˊʟ̣ī,ʼ hîn dī lʼ sūˊdagᴀn.

\eng Then it said to me, 'No, get upon me.'
\src 0360:23

\cit 003:245
\swa Waˊʟ̣u laguēˊ ł qaʟ̣īˊgᴀn ʟ̣ū lʼ t!aˊ-on xeˊtgui ł ᵋᴀˊnłtc!îgᴀn. 
\mod ʼWáadluu ʼláa gwee Hl k̲áadliigan dluu, ʼll tʼáawun xidgwíi Hl g̲ánhlätsʼägan.
\eng And when I did get upon it, I put my head under its feathers.
\src 0360:24

\cit 003:246

\mod ʼWáagyaan 'Díi gä hl g̲án_sk̲ʼáwdladas,' hín díi ʼll súudägan.
\eng And it said to me, 'Put your arms around me.
\src 0360:25

\cit 003:247

\mod 'Dáng k̲agánjuu g̲áagahls dluu hl, díi x̲áahldaang.'
\eng When your throat gets tired, scratch me.'
\src 0360:26

\cit 003:248

\mod ʼWáadluu díi dángahl ʼll g̲atlʼáagan.
\eng Then it dived with me.

\cit 003:249

\cit 003:250

\mod ʼWáagyaan gyáagw Hl k̲ʼáwgan gw ʼll dlagadíijan.
\eng And it came up in the place where I had sat.
\src 0360:29

\cit 003:251

\mod Díi dángahl ʼll g̲atlʼáasdaa sdánggan.
\eng It dived twice with me.
\src 0360:30

\cit 003:252

\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu díi ʼll k̲íitlʼaahalgan.
\eng But then it told me to look up.

\cit 003:253

\mod ʼWáadluu Hl k̲íiyaagan.
\eng At that time I did look up.
\src 0360:32

!! Swanton page 101 = 361

\cit 003:254
\swa Hao xetîˊt îs ū dīgᵃ q!ᴀˊñgᴀn,” hîn ʟ!a lʼ sūdaiˊan.
\mod Húu x̲idʼíid is uu díi gä k̲ʼánggan," hín tlʼáa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng It was that bird that helped me." This is what he told them.
\src 0361:01

\cit 003:255
\swa Gaˊ-istᴀ ᵋāl stᴀˊñᵋełs ʟ̣ū k!iäˊlū ʟgaˊʟ!as ʟ! qäˊñᴀn.
\mod Gáaysdä g̲áal sdángʼiihls dluu, kʼyáaluu tlagáatlʼaas tlʼ k̲éengaan.
\eng Two nights afterward they saw a Cormorant coming.
\src 0361:02

\cit 003:256
\swa Lnagaˊ-i ᵋa lʼ ʟ̣îgᴀˊndalan. 
\mod ʼLan-gáay g̲áa ʼll dlagándaalaan.
\eng It swam to the town.
\src 0361:03

\cit 003:257
\swa Waˊʟ̣u kiagᵃ lᴀ k!iūˊ ʟ! ᵋēˊdiwagan la dᴀ ʟ! ᵋᴀˊnaguns ʟ̣ū. 
\mod ʼWáadluu kyáa gä ʼláa kʼyuu tlʼ g̲íidiiʼwaagaan, ʼláa dä tlʼ g̲ánaagans dluu.
\eng And since all wanted to see it very much, they went outside for it.
\src 0361:04

\cit 003:258
\swa Waˊʟ̣u anᴀˊñ q!ēyâˊ x̣ūˊᴀdj tc!îgᴀˊn hîn sāˊwan “Dī ł lʼ k!ᴀtʟāˊgandaᵋo.” 
\mod ʼWáadluu aa nang k̲ʼayáa xúuwajii tsʼagán hín sáawaan, "Díi hl ʼll kʼad tláagaandäʼuu."
\eng Then the old man who had shot the grisly bear said, " Let me throw a stone at it first."
\src 0361:05
\note nice use of ʼll as object pronoun

\cit 003:259
\swa Wᴀˊgîñan ʟîgaˊ-itcaˊaiyē ᵋa-i lʼ ᵋēˊdagᴀłs ʟ̣ū qwā dᴀ ʟ! xāˊdaᵋodjawan. 
\mod ʼWáa gingáan dlagáay cháayaay g̲áay ʼll g̲íidaagahls dluu, k̲waa dä tlʼ x̲áadaa g̲ujáawaan.
\eng So when it came into shallow water, all took stones [for it].
\src 0361:06

\cit 003:260
\swa Wᴀˊgiên âˊnᴀñ q!ēˊya îs lʼ k!ᴀˊtʟāgañan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan a nang k̲ʼayáa is ʼll kʼad tláagaangaan.
\eng And the old man threw at it first.
\src 0361:07

\cit 003:261
\swa Wᴀstʼ ʟ!ao hit!ᴀˊn lʼ ᵋei ʟ! k!ᴀˊtaoyūˊanᴀñ.
\mod ʼWáa sdä tlʼaa uu hatʼán ʼll g̲ée tlʼ kʼadáaw íiwaanaan.
\eng But afterwards they threw at it a great deal.
\src 0361:08

\cit 003:262
\swa Lʼ ᵋei ʟ! k!ᴀˊdaos k!iäˊnᴀn gᴀm lʼ łᵋoaˊgałᵋañan. 
\mod ʼLl g̲ée tlʼ kʼadáaws kʼyáanan, gám ʼll hlg̲wáagahlʼaangaan.
\eng Although they threw stones at it, it was not afraid.
\src 0361:09
\note ʼll g̲ée is weird, instead of ʼlée

\cit 003:263
\swa Gᴀm st!ēˊlga-i dᴀ lʼ gudᴀˊñᵋañan. 
\mod Gám sdílgaay dä ʼll gudángʼaangaan.
\eng It did not want to go back.
\src 0361:10

\cit 003:264
\swa Wᴀˊgiên ʟan lᴀ ʟ! k!ᴀdaˊn. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan tláan ʼláa tlʼ kʼadáan.
\eng Then they stopped throwing at it.
\src 0361:11

\cit 003:265
\swa Wᴀˊgiên ʟ!a qāˊłgut lʼ qagᴀłsᵋwāˊnañᴀn. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan tlʼáa k̲áahlguud ʼll k̲áagahl sg̲wáanaangaan.
\eng And it went straight up among them.
\src 0361:12

\cit 003:266
\swa Wᴀˊgiên nᴀñ īˊʟadas gia na-i yakᵘ tīˊyuda-i ᵋa-i lʼ qatc!aiˊan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan nang íitlʼaadáas gyaa náay yahgw tíiyuudaay g̲áay ʼll k̲atsʼáayaan.
\eng Then it entered the chief's house, which stood in the middle of the town.
\src 0361:13

\cit 003:267
\swa Waˊʟ̣u la ʟ! kiänāˊñan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu ʼláa tlʼ kyáanaangaan.
\eng Then they questioned it.
\src 0361:14

\cit 003:268
\swa “Gasîˊnʟ!ao dᴀñ īˊdjîñ,” hîn ʟ! sāˊwan. 
\mod "Gasán tlʼaa uu dáng íijang?" hín tlʼ sáawaan.
\eng "Why have you come?" they said.
\src 0361:15
\note Original English: "Who are you?" they said.

\cit 003:269
\swa “Dalᴀˊñ gᵃ ł gīˊdīyē ᵋᴀn ᴀ,” hîn lʼ sāˊwan. 
\mod "Daláng gä Hl gíidayaay g̲an aa," hín ʼll sáawaan.
\eng "In order to give you food," it said.
\src 0361:16
\note Original English: It said "I am one who comes to give you food."

\cit 003:270
\swa Sao ᴀł lʼ sk!îˊsʟīyagan. 
\mod Sáaw ahl ʼll skʼisdlayáagaan.
\eng It was full of olachen.
\src 0361:17

\cit 003:271
\swa “ᴀłgui ł ᵋᴀn dīgᵃ gîn îsdaˊᵋo,” hîn lʼ sāˊwan. 
\mod "Ahlgwíi hl g̲án díi gä gin isdäʼúu," hín ʼll sáawaan.
\eng "Get me something for these," it said.
\src 0361:18

\cit 003:272
\swa Wᴀˊgîñan k!ēˊiłga yūˊᴀn la xetgᵘ ʟ! îsdaiˊan.
\mod ʼWáa gingáan k̲íihlgaa íiwaan ʼláa x̲idgw tlʼ isdáayaan.
\eng So they set a big tray in front of it.
\src 0361:19

\cit 003:273
\swa Waˊʟ̣u ʟ!ao hit!ᴀˊn sāˊwē lʼ xałīˊ stᴀ k!ēˊiłga-i ᵋa-i îsʟaiˊ-îdani. 
\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu hatʼán sáawaay ʼll x̲ahlíi sdä k̲íihlgaay g̲áay isdláahidaan ii.
\eng But then the olachen began to come out of its mouth into the tray.
\src 0361:20

\cit 003:274
\swa Wᴀˊgiên k!ēˊiłga-i staˊgani. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan k̲íihlgaay stahgáan ii.
\eng And the tray was filled.
\src 0361:21

\cit 003:275
\swa Waˊʟ̣u âˊnᴀñ īˊʟ!adas hîn sāˊwan, “Āˊdji ł gutgᵃ îˊsdaᵋo.”
\mod ʼWáadluu a nang íitlʼaadáas hín sáawaan, "Áajii hl gud gä isdäʼúu."
\eng Then the chief said, "Distribute these among yourselves."
\src 0361:22

\cit 003:276
\swa Wᴀˊgîñan gutgᵃ ʟ! îˊsdaᵋodjawani.
\mod ʼWáa gingáan gud gä tlʼ isdä g̲ujáawaan ii.
\eng So they shared them.
\src 0361:23

\cit 003:277
\swa Waˊʟ̣u hîn ʟ!a lʼ sūdaiˊan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu hín tlʼáa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng Then it said to them.
\src 0361:24

\cit 003:278
\swa “Haˊoîsîn ł ʟ̣igaˊʟ!at!ᴀs ʟ̣ū ł gᴀm dī k!ᴀdᵋᴀˊñᵋwañ.
\mod "Háwsan Hl dlagáatlʼaatʼas dluu hl, gám díi kʼadʼángʼwaang.
\eng "When I come again, do not throw stones at me.
\src 0361:25
\note Original English for the last two lines: Then it said to them, "When I come again, do not throw stones at me.  Also, a delayed imperative with 3pl -ʼwa.

\cit 003:279

\mod Háwsan daláng gä sáaw Hl isdáaäsaang."
\eng I will give you olachen again."
\src 0361:26

\cit 003:280

\mod Gu g̲ándlasii sdä ʼll ijáan.
\eng It came from Nass River.
\src 0361:27

\cit 003:281

\mod ʼWáadluu hatʼán tlʼáa sdä ʼll k̲agáalaan.
\eng Then it went away from them.
\src 0361:28

\cit 003:282

\mod Gáaysdä g̲áal sdángʼiihls dluu, hásan ʼll dlagáatlʼaagaan.
\eng Two nights afterward it came over again.
\src 0361:29

\cit 003:283

\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu gám ʼláa tlʼ kʼadáaʼaangaan.
\eng But then they did not throw stones at it.
\src 0361:30

\cit 003:284

\mod ʼWáagyaan híikʼwaan dámaan ʼláa tlʼ k̲éengaan.
\eng And they took good care of it.
\src 0361:31

\cit 003:285

\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll k̲áagahls gyaan, nang íitlʼaagädáas gyaa náay g̲áay ʼll k̲atsʼáayaan.
\eng And when it went up, it entered the chief's house.
\src 0361:32

\cit 003:286
\swa Waˊʟ̣u haˊoîsîn giˊnᴀ ᵋa-i ʟ!agᵃ lʼ îsdaiˊani ᵋᴀn lʼ gināˊñan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu háwsan gin g̲áay tlʼáa gä ʼll isdáayaan ii g̲an ʼll gináangaan.
\eng Then it again asked for something in which to put them.
\src 0362:01

\cit 003:287

\mod ʼWáa gingáan ʼláa x̲idgw tlʼ isdáayaan ii.

\cit 003:288

\mod ʼWáadluu tlʼaa uu háwsan sáawaay ʼwée ʼll g̲áangaan ii.

\src 0362:03

\cit 003:290

\mod ʼWáagyaan háwsan nang íitlʼaadáas, "Áajii hl gud gä isdä g̲ujúu," hín sáawaan.
\eng And again the chief said, "Give all of these to the people."
\src 0362:05

\cit 003:291

\mod ʼWáadluu gud gä tlʼ isdä g̲ujáawaan ii.
\eng Then the people shared them.
\src 0362:06

\cit 003:292

\mod Áajii tlʼáa gä tlʼ isdä g̲íihlgiis dluu, "Nang íihlangaa k̲atlʼaʼáang gwaa," hín tlʼ sáawaan.
\eng After all had been given to them, they said, "A man is coming."

\cit 003:293

\cit 003:294

\mod "k̲úng k̲áatlʼaahlgangas gúusdä uu ʼll k̲áagan," hín tlʼ sáawaan.
\eng They said, "He is coming from the direction of the moonrise."

\mod Yáahl uu ijáan.

\cit 003:298

\cit 003:300

\mod "Nang íitlʼaadáas, kʼwáay sáaw díi gä gíidaadaa," nang íitlʼaadáas ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng He said to the chief, "Chief, let them give me olachen."

\cit 003:301

\mod "Gáaʼanuu, angáa tlʼ k̲uyáadä g̲ujúugang," hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng "No, they like it too well," he (the chief) said to him.

\cit 003:302

\mod ʼWáagyaan háwsan ginán ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng And he said the same thing to him again.

\cit 003:303

\mod ʼWáagyaan g̲adúu ʼll kihl g̲isgáayaan ii.
\eng And he could not get it by talking.
\src 0362:18

\cit 003:304
\swa “Hawaˊn ł qēˊsalgᴀñgua,” hîn lʼ sūs k!iäˊnᴀn gᴀm lagᵃ gīˊdiē da ʟ! gūdᴀˊñᵋᴀñgañan.
\mod "Hawáan Hl k̲íisalgang gwaa," hín ʼll súus kʼyáanan, gám ʼláa gä gíidayaay dä tlʼ gudángʼanggaangaan.
\eng He said, "I have eaten nothing since leaving home," but still they did not want to give him food.
\src 0362:19

\cit 003:305

\mod "Gúusd uu áa daláng gä sáaw isdagáangaan?" hín tlʼáa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng "Who gave the olachen to you?" he said to them.
\src 0362:20
\note interesting use of <aa> with a question word, as well as a past-tense-marked wh-question

\cit 003:306
\swa “A k!iäˊlu q!awāˊs ū wᴀˊgᴀñgua,” hîn lᴀ ʟ! sūdaiˊan.
\mod "Áa kʼyáaluu k̲ʼáwaas uu ʼwáagan gwaa," hín ʼláa tlʼ súudaayaan.
\eng "This Cormorant did it," they said to him.
\src 0362:21

\cit 003:307
\swa Waˊʟ̣u la-o lʼ qêñ qa-aod gᴀm gᵘ dīgᵃ îˊsîn dᴀñ waˊłiñañ,” hîn la lʼ sūdaiˊan. 
\mod ʼWáadluu ʼláa uu ʼll k̲íng k̲áwd, "Gám gw díi gä isán dáng ʼwáa hlangáaʼang?" hín ʼláa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng And after he had looked at it (the Cormorant) for a while, he said to it, "Will you not give me some also?"
\src 0362:22
\note negative yes/no question -- funny ending on verb?

\cit 003:308
\swa Wᴀgiêˊn ga la lʼ gwaˊwaiyan.
\mod ʼWáagyaan ga ʼláa ʼll gwáawaayaan.
\eng And it refused to do so.
\src 0362:23

\cit 003:309
\swa “Haoʟ̣naˊn dᴀñ qwaiˊᵋēłsga,” hîn waˊʟ̣u Yêˊlē k!iäˊluwē sūdaiˊan. 
\mod "Húudlʼanaan dáng k̲waʼáayʼiihlsgaa," hín ʼwáadluu Yáalaay kʼyáaluwaay súudaayaan.
\eng Then Raven said to the Cormorant, "You shall become stone where you are."
\src 0362:24

\cit 003:310
\swa Wᴀˊgiên lʼ qwaaˊ-iᵋelan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan ʼll k̲waʼáayʼeelaan.
\eng And it became a stone.
\src 0362:25

\cit 003:311
\swa “Gᴀm ł īʟ! L!ākuˊnsudan, nᴀñ īˊʟ!adas,” hîn la ʟ! sūdaiˊan. 
\mod "Gám hl íitlʼ tlʼáag únsuudaan, nang íitlʼaadáas," hín ʼláa tlʼ súudaayaan.
\eng "Do not speak that way to us, chief," they said to him.
\src 0362:26
\note the verb, whatever it is, should have Neg suffix on it

\cit 003:312
\swa Lagᵃ ʟ! łᵋoaˊgalan. 
\mod ʼLáa gä tlʼ hlg̲wáagaalaan.
\eng They were afraid of him.
\src 0362:27

\cit 003:313
\swa “Wᴀt!ᴀˊlgᵃ hᴀn gᴀm dī dalᴀˊñ gīˊd-aᵋañgᴀñgua. 
\mod ʼWáa tʼálgä han, "Gám díi daláng gíidäʼanggan gwaa.
\eng But still, "You did not give me food.
\src 0362:28
\note Iʼve moved the quote to start at gám

\cit 003:314
\swa Dalᴀˊñ îˊsîn qwaˊa-iᵋēłsañ,” hîn ʟ!a lʼ sūdaiˊan. 
\mod Daláng isán k̲waʼáayʼiihlsaang," hín tlʼáa ʼll súudaayaan.
\eng You shall also become stones," he said to them.
\src 0362:29
\note Original English for the last two lines:  But still he said to them, "You did not give me food. You shall also become stones."

\cit 003:315
\swa Wᴀˊgiên ʟ! waˊ-aʟ̣uᴀn qwaˊa-iᵋelan. 
\mod ʼWáagyaan tlʼ ʼwáadluwaan k̲waʼáayʼeelaan.
\eng And all became stones.
\src 0362:30
\note 'wáaaaadluwaan  :)

\cit 003:316
\swa Saˊwē da lʼ gudᴀˊñs ʟ̣ū lʼ wᴀˊgan. 
\mod Sáawaay dä ʼll gudángs dluu ʼll ʼwáagaan.
\eng He did it because he wanted the olachen.
\src 0362:31

\cit 003:317
\swa Wᴀk!iêˊnᴀn sawēˊ dᴀˊñᴀłan qwaˊa-iᵋēlani. 
\mod ʼWáakʼyaanan sáawaay dángahlaan k̲waʼáayʼeelaan ii.
\eng But yet the olachen turned into stones along with them.
\src 0362:32

\cit 003:318
\swa Hao ʟīˊsʟ̣u la kuˊndjuga.
\mod Háw tlíisdluu ʼláa kúnjuugaa.
\eng The end.
\src 0362:33
